tit.e: "Jishi Menkyo" (The Exemption From The Tax That Was Imposed On The land Of The Town's Residential Area During The Early Modern Ages Of Japan)

sen.j: 地子免許（じしめんきょ）とは、近世の都市において町屋敷地にかかる地子（農村の年貢に相当する）を領主権力が免除すること。
sen.e: "Jishi menkyo" refers to the exemption from "jishi" (the tax imposed on the land of the town's residential area during the early modern ages of Japan) permitted by a feudal lord, and jishi corresponded to "nengu" (the tax imposed on the land of farming villages).

sen.j: 地子免除が行われるのにはいくつかの背景がある。
sen.e: There were some backgrounds on jishi menkyo.

sen.j: まず領主による都市、特に城下町・宿場町などでの商工業振興のための町人誘致の目的が指摘されている。
sen.e: Firstly, it is pointed out that the feudal lord planned to attract merchants to the town - especially, to the castle town and to the post station town - for the promotion of commerce and industry.

sen.j: 第二に中世以来の「無縁」概念（都市をアジールとする考え）との関連性も指摘されている。
sen.e: Secondly, it is also pointed out that jishi menkyo had a connection with the concept from the medieval ages that the town was the "asylum" (the area on which the political power could not exert its sovereignty).

sen.j: もっとも地子免許＝租税免除ではない。
sen.e: However, jishi menkyo did not mean the complete tax exemption.

sen.j: すなわち、必要に応じた賦課を課すことに対する代償として恒常的な地子の免除が行われたとも考えられる。
sen.e: Constant jishi was exempt for sure, but this seems to have been in exchange for the provisional imposition that was put when necessary.

sen.e: In some cities, the rights on land were so complicated that it was impossible to determine who should bear the burden, and instead, a new tax system of the city seems to have been introduced.

sen.e: And in some areas, including the area which is now called Okayama City, the city boundary and the rights on land were determined, so jishi was imposed on the residents throughout the early modern ages.

sen.e: And in some areas, including the area which is now called Kanazawa City, the jishi-imposed area (called "jishi-cho") and the exempt area (called "hon-cho") were separated.

sen.e: In some cities - newborn ones and renewed ones - such as Edo, residents offered "kuniyaku" (public duties) to the feudal lord at the early stage of the city development, and in exchange, they received the land of the town's residential area that were newly developed.

sen.e: And then, the regime of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI gave jishi menkyo to the whole "Rakuchu" (inside the capital Kyoto) after the Rakuchu land survey was implemented in 1591.

sen.j: だが、明治政府は全ての土地から地税を徴収する（免税地を認めない）方針を打ちたて、明治4年（1871年）に地租改正に先立って地子免除が廃止された。
sen.e: However, the Meiji government formulated the policy of collecting land tax from every land - in other words, permitted no tax-free land - and in 1871, it abandoned the jishi menkyo before the Land Tax Reform.
